newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity ends higher though seen capped.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity ends higher though seen capped.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures ended higher Tuesday in line with stronger natural gas futures but were capped by lower spot power prices and expectations of possibly significant hydroelectric availability, sources said.

January California Oregon Border (COB) power futures finished up 36 cents at $24.11 per megawatt hour (MWh) after morning trade as low as $23.40, while February COB ended up nine cents at $18.80 per MWh.
Remaining COB deferreds settled steady from Monday's closes.
January Palo Verde (PV) finished up 50 cents at $24.75 after trade as low as $23.75, while February closed down 77 cents at $19.38 after trade as low as $18.75 per MWh.
Remaining PV deferreds settled steady to $1.00 higher.

Although natural gas futures surged strongly higher, traders said electricity futures were capped by concern over the possibility of strong hydroelectric availability in the U.S. Northwest, the sources said.
In a move considered bearish for western electricity, Bonneville Power Administration (BPA) on Tuesday offered next-day surplus peak power for sale for the first time in almost two weeks.
"If BPA had not been in the market today we would have seen a bigger rally, (electricity futures) probably would have followed gas higher," said one futures trader.
January Henry Hub natural gas futures finished up 17.4 cents at $3.396 per million British thermal units on Tuesday.
Spot next day peak power in the U.S. Northwest fell Tuesday to $22.00-23.25 per MWh, while Southwest power held relatively steady at $22.00-23.00 per MWh.
NYMEX said an estimated total of 200 COB and 239 PV contracts traded Tuesday.
